Message.Title: Valve's Gabe Newell Warns That Game Consoles Should Fear Apple
Message.Msg: The threat right now is that Apple has gained a huge amount of market share, and has a relatively obvious pathway towards entering the living room with their platform,” Newell said. “I think that there’s a scenario where we see sort of a dumbed down living room platform emerging — I think Apple rolls the console guys really easily. The question is can we make enough progress in the PC space to establish ourselves there, and also figure out better ways of addressing mobile before Apple takes over the living room?”

Topic.Title: Valve's Gabe Newell Warns That Game Consoles Should Fear Apple

Message.Msg: A game console would answer some of the content questions now dogging Apple TV – if it’s not sold primarily as a set-top box, then it removes some of the onus for the company to completely reform the cable industry. Instead, we could find ourselves with, basically, a souped-up iPad that can run games and other apps through the living room TV. Plug a controller in there and you’ve got yourselves a console. Apple’s move into the living room is inevitable at this point – especially now, with the world looking to Tim Cook to prove he can launch a truly new product like Steve Jobs could. As Newell says, the real question now is timing – can any of these other companies successfully establish themselves as the go-to mainstream living room OS before Apple makes its move? It’s anybody’s game.

Topic.Title: Serious: When will AAPL put cash to WORK?

Message.Msg: Maybe AAPL plans a buyback when the stock is at a bargain price? When I look at growth, yields, and price-over-earnings, and compare AAPL to AMZN, it seems that maybe wall street is dumb enough to drive the price of AAPL to even better bargain prices. Then would be a good time to start a buyback and double the dividend to get the price of AAPL to rocket up to $1000 per share and a price over earnings of 19. GOOG didn't have much luck with shareholder price when they invested more cash into wind or solar electric power generation. And AAPL probably doesn't say much about what's in their development pipeline because new products in the future may cause current sales to decline when customers stop buying to wait for the next product. So I guess AAPL will continue to make new products and may do buybacks when the price of AAPL reaches a bottom.

Message.Title: The Looming Living Room Wars: Apple’s Quiet Threat to Console Gaming
Message.Msg: Imagine: Your ultra-chic future iPhone isn’t just a sometime mobile game machine, it’s also a wireless vehicle for hardcore gaming on your big screen television. Maybe it works with a wireless gamepad, maybe it uses ultra-low electrical current that lets your fingertips “feel” the edges of control surfaces along your iPad or iPhone’s perfectly flat glass screen. Either way, imagine that it’s the future of serious and casual gaming, a future in which dedicated set-top boxes, cables and marathon life cycles shuffle grudgingly into that good night. For years I’ve made the argument that Apple‘s iOS platform is just a wireless gamepad and HDTV-hookup away from squaring off against Microsoft, Sony and Nintendo in the living room. Take the iPhone 5 with its 1.3 GHz A6 processor and triple-core PowerVR SGX 543MP3 GPU, outputting console-quality visuals to a virtually 720p screen. No one’s run meaningful comparison benchmarks between the iPhone 5 and, say, the Xbox 360, but we’ve seen actual game developers suggest that the iPhone 5 is on par, performance-wise, with Microsoft’s seven-year-old console (to say nothing of the tricked-out A6X processor in the fourth-generation iPad, which probably surpasses it).

Message.Title: Somethings funny in what is being reported....
Message.Msg: From CNN Money..... FORTUNE -- According to a report issued Friday by Net Applications, the Web presence of Android devices peaked in November at 28% and has been drifting down ever since. By contrast, Apple's (AAPL) iOS has climbed since October, after the company launched the iPhone 5 and the iPad mini. That quite a different story than the one being told by market research firms like IDC, which has Samsung's Android-based smartphones outselling the iPhone and Samsung's tablets rapidly catching up to Apple's iPad. "IDC says Android is the new king of tablet market share," was Thursday's headline on CNNMoney. I was skeptical of IDC's tablet shipment numbers Thursday, given that of the major tablet manufacturers, only Apple actually releases unit sales data. And I'm doubly skeptical today, given the trends shown in Net Applications' data above. Unlike IDC, which seems to pull numbers out of thin air, Net Applications is actually counting something: The browser data from 160 million users per month weighted geographically according to the number of users in each country. (StatCounter, a competing service, does not weigh its data geographically and gets very different results.) How can Google's (GOOG) Android be the king of tablets and smartphones if more than 60% of Web users are on Apple devices and only 24.5% on Android? Either a lot of Android owners are not using their devices to surf the Web -- which is certainly possible -- or someone's numbers are screwy.

Topic.Title: Somethings funny in what is being reported....

Message.Msg: The most likely explanation for that is that they are both true, that Android is gaining market share but slowing web presence, and that IOS is gaining web presence but losing share. How is that? Depends on how the devices are being used. One could easily presume IOS users in aggregate to be much wealthier than Android users. By far. One aspect of this disparity in wealth and/or income is the lack of access to broadband wifi at home, school and at work (if there is a job to go to) for Android users. Therefore, many Android users rely, disproportionately, on their cellular data plans than do IOS users, greatly reducing their ability to surf the web freely (data limits etc.). Remember, for most Android users, their smart phone is their sole computing device. They can't afford another. This fact also explains why they prefer the clown like large screens and form factors. It's the only screen they have. So bigger for them is better. This is especially true in more developing nations where one smart phone is the computing device for an entire family. This is my opinion, but I feel it is mostly right.

Message.Title: $190 Billion Cash by Year-End = $606 Stock
Message.Msg: This past quarter AAPL had $17 Billion pos. cashflow, so total of $137 billion cash equivalents on its Bal. Sheet with No Debt ! That's $5.7 billion more cash per month ( or more added in 1 month than Amazon's no profit strategy has after 15 years in business ). If Apple only adds bit less $5 billion per month for the next 11 months of 2013, it will therefore have approx. $190 billion in cash on its books by year-end 2013. If we multiply very conservative 3X cash for a Valuation = $570 Billion, divided by 940 million AAPL Shares = $606 minimum price by year-end 2013. ITS SIMPLE MATH.

Topic.Title: AAPL Will Run Back Over $600 Per-Share In 2013. AAPL Pay's $11 Per-Share In Dividends

Message.Msg: Apple's problem is very simple. Management and the board don't care about you. Shareholders are not part of what they concern themselves with. None of them are long any significant stakes in Apple stock with most holding zero shares to a few hundred (check insider roster). Why do you think money is hoarded to these absurd levels and the buyback only offsets stock grant dilution? Until management does a 180 and cares about shareholders this stock will always huge insanely low multiples. The market believes the cash from apple's bank never makes its way into the hands of the shareholders. It is expected they build the hoard to only one day burn through it when cash flow goes negative down the road sometime. Apple "could" fix all this with a 20 dollar plus dividend and a 50B to 100B buyback but the important word is "could". They won't do it and that is why this is not going to beat the market over the next year, two years and 5 years. Key word being "won't" because they do not care. Actions speak louder than words and look at what they have done. Words also speak loud on the conference call where they made it clear they have no intention of changing the current dividend or buyback and how great they are for returning 45B over 3 years. Well 10B of that just offsets stock option grants. Thanks but no thanks. And 10.60 dividend? Keep the change. You make 45/share per year and have 140/share in the bank. Is that all you can part with? HOpefully this helps some longs realize what is going on here. I sold 95% of my apple holdings I held for 5 years the moment they answered the question on the conference call about how they have no intentions of changing how they are treating their cash and shareholders

Message.Title: Apple (AAPL) Becomes Top U.S. Smartphone Vendor for First Time Ever
Message.Msg: "According to Strategy Analytics, Apple shipped 17.7 million units in the final quarter of last year, topping Samsung's 16.8 million shipment number. The number puts Apple with a U.S. market share of 34 percent, versus 32.3 percent for Samsung. Apple's market share is up from just 25.4 percent in Q411, while Samsung improved from 26.9 percent. In total, the U.S. smartphone market grew a modest 3.6 percent to 52.0 million units last quarter and shrank 10.7 percent for 2012." With its fiscal first-quarter 2013 results, Apple reported iPhone shipments of 47.8 million units, up 29 percent over the prior year.

Message.Title: AAPL takes top mobile phone vendor spot
Message.Msg: "For the last five years Samsung has held strong as the number one mobile phone vendor in the United States, in large part thanks both to high end Android devices like the Galaxy S3 and Note 2, and lower-end devices as well. Now Apple has finally taken their spot, for the 4th quarter of 2012, selling 17.7 million iPhones. In comparison, Samsung sold 16.8 million phones and LG was a distant third at 4.7 million. So is this a change that will stick? Probably not. Momentum from the iPhone 5 could be a big part of this Q4 gain. While Apple does very well in the United States, it is hard to compete with Samsung’s massive line-up of both smartphones and feature phones. Its also known that the Samsung Galaxy S4 isn’t too terribly far away from launching. For the whole year, Samsung was the leader in fact. It was just in Q4 that things swung in Apple’s favor. Still, it’s hard not to be impressed that Apple manages such a large amount of marketshare with just a few iPhone models on sale (iPhone 5, iPhone 4S, iPhone 4) versus the countless number of Samsung, LG and other Android phones on the market."

Message.Title: AAPL is still number one investment opportunity.
Message.Msg: Apple Inc. AAPL -0.99% was tied for first among the 40-plus billionaires tracked by the index, with 18 mega-investors holding at least $10 million worth of the stock at the end of the last 13F filing period with the SEC. Apple's swoon has been well-documented by all corners of the blogosphere, but shares are still up more than 11% since the start of 2012. The tech giant is clearly oversold at its current levels, and the company has a number of potential growth drivers — a deal with China Mobile, a smart TV and a dividend hike among chief importance — that can push shares to a fairer price. Some of the top-name investors in Apple include David Tepper , Dan Loeb and David Einhorn.

Message.Title: This is why AAPL has no more traction
Message.Msg: AAPL was able to bring on the market 4 amazing products one after the other one, the Macbook air, the iPod, the iPhone, and the iPad. The money started pouring into the coffer at a substantial pace. This feat has stopped. Not one new product for a while, safe Tide improved already existing ones. The forecast revenue tells all, between $41B and $43B for March compare to last year $39B, or a paltry 10% increase at best. And no product in sight, except the same rumor of a TV for 8 months now. Even if they bring a TV in the fall, their actual products are seeing more and more competition, meaning more and more pressure on their revenue. Topic.Title: If I wanted to buy a PUT contract, how would I do that

Message.Msg: 1. Ask your broker to approve you for option trading, this usually involves a form you have to fill out and you have to fill out and it takes a few days to process (at Schwab anyway). 2. Once you are approved, your broker can buy the put for you - Schwab has a tab on the web page called option trading. Commissions are a lot more than for stocks, but vary from broker to broker so look up the commission trader for your broker. Keep in mind that you have to multiply the price of the contract by 100x, since they list prices per share instead of per contract. So if the contract has a price of $25, you will pay $2500.

Topic.Title: If I wanted to buy a PUT contract, how would I do that

Message.Msg: I wouldn't open puts at this juncture today. This is why the 5-min momentum charts are useful. Wait for the 10-period 5-min momentum to (spike/drop) to extreme (highs/lows) then you at least have a fightin chance to enter the position at some level of risk avoidance. Otherwise, you're buying on emotion and may catch the extreme opposites of what you could get had you waited for the momentum signal. You may not catch exact top or bottom in price at that moment, but you at least enter better than you would otherwise without a road map. Same goes for calls.

Topic.Title: what can I say, the best company, the worst stock

Message.Msg: This has happened in the market before, where quality companies are seen as "boring", and speculative companies that buy market share by losing money selling product at cost or losing on each sale (Amazon's Kindle Fire sold at cost) is somehow seen as growth. Amazon has $5 billion total cash on its balance sheet after 15 years being in business, not even from retained earnings. Amazon was a $10 stock in 2002, and makes same money now, about $0 profit. Apple has piled up over $5 billion MORE in cash in just some months in the past year.

Message.Title: DeMark's comments
Message.Msg: ...Apple Stock Could Pop Monday: DeMark "It seems outrageous," says Market Studies CEO Tom DeMark, but indicators suggest that Apple shares could open up next week. Although it might seem "outrageous," Apple shares could open up next week, Market Studies CEO Tom DeMark said Friday on CNBC. "If you look at Apple's entire decline, the most number of consecutive down days has been three," he said on "Fast Money." Apple's share price declined three days in a row on Dec. 14, after which it climbed, and again on Dec. 21, followed by the stock trading sideways. On Friday, Apple stock posted three consecutive days of losses, which DeMark noted were within "a very narrow trading range." "That typically is indicative of a market turn," he said. "It would not be outrageous to expect a gap up on Monday," he said. "We could turn to the upside on Monday and produce an island reversal."

Message.Title: Definition of an "island Reversal"
Message.Msg: An island reversal is a chart formation where there is a gap on both sides of the candle. Island reversals frequently show up after a trending move is in its final stages. An island reversal gets it name from the fact that the candlestick appears to be all alone, as if on an island. A key sign of a valid island reversal is an increase on volume on both the first gap, and then the subsequent gap in the opposite direction. An island reversal formation is often attributed to news driven events that occur in the pre-market or after-hours trading.

Selling fewer iPhones in the last quarter than some wanted but more cell phones in the USA than anyone else is not a good reason. T-Mobile with its new merger with MetroPCS will start to offer iPhones shortly. There will be a contract with China Mobile announced in the near future. New products that nobody had ever thought that they needed will come out sometime in the future and be blockbusters. The time to buy Apple or any other stock is when people like you question the future.

Topic.Title: today's trading makes complete sense

Message.Msg: OK, here's more complete logic: AAPL just sold off big time. From a high of $700/share, down to today's price (which now is almost back to the open price, a very good sign and confirmation of support @ $450/share). NOBODY WANTS TO CATCH A FALLING KNIFE. So, everyone is sitting around, waiting, watching, seeing if it is done dropping before they buy in. Nothing here to whine about ... AAPL has just been in the control of traders for awhile. I heard on NPR that it was part of a "pair trade" that was recently reversed, for example long AAPL short RIMM. A recent article on seekiingalpha titled "Several Theories To Explain Apple's Nosedive" has "Theory 4 - Long Apple and short everything else?" which is essentially this "pair trade". Of course the market is a friggin' casino, if you don't know that you are stupid and shouldn't be gambling your money here. So, anyways, IMO it is very bullish that AAPL has found support after such a steep drop, and you longs (I'm one of them, probably at a better cost basis than most) should just be patient for the rebound. It will only come when there is positive news about the company. Otherwise, nobody wants to take the risk to buy back in yet. There, is that good enough logic for you?

Apple's press release emphasized that all Fortune 500 and 85% of Global 500 companies are currently deploying or testing the iPad. Devices powered by iOS have opened the door for Apple in the enterprise market where OS X could never. So it comes as no surprise to hear that Apple has acquired some rather high-end enterprise-class software to take the iPad to the next level. Yesterday, Montreal based Maya-Systems revealed in a press release that they sold user interface patents to Apple relating to their Axis-based technology which is behind their IamOrganized workflow management tool that is cloud based.

Topic.Title: Any serious advice here?

Message.Msg: My advice is this: don't put all your eggs in one basket. I've made this same mistake over and over again, holding onto a loser hoping it will return and gotten burned. It's easy to do. Once a stock breaks its 200 dma on a chart, it is difficult to comeback. The good thing Apple has going for it is great fundamentals so I don't think it is a broken company as some will make you think. Apple has value and lots of cash. Tim Cook and Oppenheimer, his CFO, have had too many earnings disappointments and have exposed Apple to extreme and yes, overdone, negative sentiment. What I would suggest and I am doing myself is next time we see a big bump up, take some off the table, put it in more stable companies. I have had wonderful returns with companies such as IBM, PSX, CVX, MCD. These are long term and even some of these have given much gyration near term if a bad comp sales report hits the wires, or inventories are bad, yada yada. Diversify. Keep some Apple too. Amazing is when the others are down, Apple may be up and it will help ease the pain. That's the best advice I can give you. Trust me you aren't the only one who got burned. Last report wasn't bad, but the guidance call and pisspour conference call turned off most analysts and unfortunately they can make you or break you.

Topic.Title: Any serious advice here?

Message.Msg: Last year I invested AAPL both long and short. I would either buy stock and sell calls, or sell puts, but most often I would buy both calls and puts and ride one side profitably. The stock moves so fast that this is a very worthwhile strategy to consider. Starting September for some reason I cannot comprehend, I started lightening up my put positions a bit too aggressively and got killed in a few large down draft days. I never recovered. Strangles and straddles work very well in this kind of a stock. Ofcourse you could simply write calls but the stock is expensive so after losses it's hard to not put your eggs in one basket as some are suggesting. This is why I say buy straddles or spreads. Right now I am all long. About 10-15 calls in the 500 range for April.

Message.Title: Apple energy patent
Message.Msg: Apple's On-Demand System for Generation of Electricity from Stored Wind Energy Solves Problems of Wind Fluctuation without utilizing batteries. Apple's invention provides a system that generates electricity. During operation, the system uses a set of rotating blades to convert rotational energy from a wind turbine into heat in a low-heat-capacity fluid. Next, the system selectively transfers the heat from the low-heat-capacity fluid to a working fluid. Finally, the system uses the transferred heat in the working fluid to generate electricity.

Topic.Title: Any serious advice here?

Message.Msg: I am seriously thinking of doubling down via long term calls. Could be a disaster but Apple is too strong fundamentally to not approach $600 or more over the next year. Shoot, cash is worth 30% of hte capitalization. Current valuation assumes 30% declines over the foreseeable future. 200 Billion iTunes downloads in 2012. That's not going to go away anytime soon. iCloud. Not going away.International e Apps. Not going away. Tablets and phones may be lower mkt % but the markets are growing. iPhone is actually increasing share in US. A lot of EU share shrinkage is EU is in tough financial times. International economies are turning around; iPhone is still the choice, albeit pricey. Projected margins according to aapl outlook look to be solid. Margins rival the best of software companies. This is still a growing business; not 50-70% but 20% is real. DMAs change and when the 50 dma crosses 200 dma the technicals will scream upside.

Message.Title: Apple is still FIRST in the U. S.
Message.Msg: The launch of the iPhone 5 and the declining popularity of non-smartphones have made Apple the biggest seller of phones in the U.S. for the first time, research firm Strategy Analytics said Friday. The firm estimates that Apple shipped 17.7 million iPhones of all kinds to U.S. buyers in the October to December period, meaning it accounted for one in three new phones. Samsung Electronics of Korea was close behind, shipping 16.8 million phones, including non-smart ones. Samsung has been the largest seller of phones to the U.S. market since 2008, Strategy Analytics said. Worldwide, Samsung is still the biggest phone vendor with 23 percent of the market, according to another research firm, IDC. Apple is number three, with 9.9 percent of the market. In between sits Nokia with 17.9 percent. Samsung beats Apple even when only smartphones are considered. It shipped 63.7 million units worldwide versus Apple's 47.8 million. IPhones are more expensive than most Samsung smartphones. So, they're well within reach for U.S. buyers, but not for buyers in the developing world, where cheaper phones running Google Inc.'s Android operating system dominate.

Topic.Title: Any serious advice here?

Message.Msg: IRS: Cheapest Obamacare Plan Will Be $20,000 Per Family January 31, 2013 Barack Obama, Kathleen Sebelius, Nancy Pelosi President Barack Obama hugs HHS Secretary Kathleen Sebelius and then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi after signing the Obamacare law on March 23, 2010. (White House photo/Pete Souza) (CNSNews) – In a final regulation issued Wednesday, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) assumed that under Obamacare the cheapest health insurance plan available in 2016 for a family will cost $20,000 for the year. Under Obamacare, Americans will be required to buy health insurance or pay a penalty to the IRS. The IRS's assumption that the cheapest plan for a family will cost $20,000 per year is found in examples the IRS gives to help people understand how to calculate the penalty they will need to pay the government if they do not buy a mandated health plan. The examples point to families of four and families of five, both of which the IRS expects in its assumptions to pay a minimum of $20,000 per year for a bronze plan.

Message.Title: Is being frustrated with management legitimate?
Message.Msg: I believe we're dealing with a broken stock as opposed to a broken company. My question is, what is management's responsibility to address this issue, in what is now becoming more than a short term correction? I don't know if a dividend increase, stock split or buy back would help? It might. Is management's job to simply guide the company in the manner they feel is best, with no regard to the movement of the stock? Maybe, I don't know. That's why I'm curious to other's opinions. As a shareholder with a fairly significant number of shares at $499, I'm getting aggravated at the silence from Apple mgt. This is arguably the most profitable company in the world, even on it's worst day.

Topic.Title: Any serious advice here?

Message.Msg: Like you, I'm long AAPL at well over $600. I didn't believe the sell off, but now it's obvious that growth money took it up tp $700 and growth money took it down. The little people got caught and were sliced and diced. It's now a long term proposition to hold this puppy, but we're missing out on the incredible run right now. We are in the "dead money" zone, and will be for some time. When the market corrects, we might be better off since the holders perhaps are becoming more and more value investors. In any event, depending on your cost basis, you should make the decision to hold as a long term play, or get out and place your bets elsewhere...short term is nowhere.....

Message.Msg: You know what, you're right. But the put options premiums are dropping in price, as they approach expiration. Unless you have a major sell-off of 10-15 points in a month, options prices won't keep up with declining time value premium, coupled with lesser implied volatilty. You need more than $1.87 drops in a day to make hay. Unless you're daytrading on the 5-min momentum swings, and are nimble enough to hit the open/close trigger fast enough. In that case, you can make more money on the daily swings then buying and holding options to expiration.

Message.Title: Stock Price Is Catching Up With All The Disasters, Nothing More Than That..
Message.Msg: Its been one disaster after another. First the much anticipated iPhone 5 never happened when everyone thought it was going to happen. We got iPhone 4S instead. No major breakthrough except for Siri which now is looked upon as sort of a joke. It sells well but seems like it is last hurrah. iPhone 5 comes out, still not anything epic and to add insult to injury the Maps fiasco happens w purplehazegate and scratchgate tagging along. Then key executives either quit or get booted. Next up are supply issues. Supposedly Cook is having problems managing the supply chain so now there is not enough inventory to meet demand. Then Apple is late to the party with iPad mini which is selling but they are still losing market share to Samsung, Google, Amazon and others. New catalysts like iTV seem to be vaporware. To make it even worse there are questions every day if Apple is still cool, has it lost its mojo. Add 4 earnings misses out of 6 reports and Its all very troubling.

Message.Title: New thought on the AAPL sell off (for myself)
Message.Msg: For many, AAPL was perceived as a safe haven investment, right up there with Gold, Treasuries, or Cash. Now, my point is not to argue the safety of those investments, bc a case could be made that they are not as safe as they are often perceived to be, it is rather that as they were perceived as safe to many, so was AAPL. As the recent market rally attests, a state of risk taking, dare I say near euphoria, has spread to the broader market. In other words, the days of parking cash in AAPL are behind us as institutional money and retail investors are now investing in stocks less cautiously again. So, combine the perceived slowing growth at AAPL, tax sell off, increased competition, new product lull and a new bull market and AAPL is where it is today. That said, AAPL may not see large inflows until these trends reverse, all of which will happen, including seeing AAPL as a safe haven bc of their cash horde, as the market corrects and sells off in April or May of this year.

Message.Title: AAPL Poised to Exploit a Bullish Technical Scenario
Message.Msg: Apple Inc. (AAPL) has not participated at all in the Dec 31-present advance of 8.2% in the SPX. In fact, AAPL has declined 18% during the same timeframe. "That said, near- and medium-term technical set-up in AAPL is positioned for a $50-$60 rally that could start at just about any hour now, as the price structure traverses its Sept 2012 down-channel from 435 towards 510." Based on the current set-up, the last 7 sessions represent a potential "Island Cluster," which in English means that all of the action since Jan 24 is clustered in a $20 range off of the low at 435, in the aftermath of a powerful down-gap left behind on Jan 24, the morning after earnings were released. If any news or a positive catalyst emerges that triggers a higher opening in the upcoming sessions, AAPL will leave behind an "Island Cluster" that will have very bullish technical implications.

Message.Title: Turkish iPad DEAL WORTH $4.5B to AAPL
Message.Msg: Friday, February 01, 2013, 07:00 pm Apple exec John Couch meets with Turkish president over possible $4.5B iPad buy Apple's Vice President of Education John Couch on Friday sat down with Turkish President Abdullah Gül in a meeting covering a possible education initiative worth $4.5 billion, as well as the incorrect layout of the Turkish "F-keyboard." photo on AI site -- turkish blog has video of what loooks like a Heads of State conference. Apple VP John Couch (right) discusses an education initiative with Turkish President Abdullah Gül (left). Source: President of Turkey's official website According to Turkish blog Ima Dergisi, Couch was joined by other Apple executives in his meeting with President Gül, which reportedly focused on an educational initiative to put up to 15 million iPads in the hands of Turkey's young students. Worth some $4.5 billion, the tablet program has Apple pushing for a contract, but a deal has yet to be reached as the parties negotiate further... Most recently, Turkey was introduced to the iPhone 5 on Dec. 14, less than two weeks after Apple launched the iTunes Music Store in the region as part of a 56-country rollout.

Topic.Title: After tax selling large hedges can't buy back in until about 30 days after

Message.Msg: The first guy is wrong because hedge funds don't sell "for tax reasons"... have you not heard of "carried interest?" Do some reading. The second guy is just plain #$%$. To the extent a filer has tax losses in a prior period, he needs to wait 31 days to rebuy the stock to avoid wash sale rules. That the stock has continued down means only that any sales in December were fortunate. That downtrend has already begun to reverse now.

Topic.Title: After tax selling large hedges can't buy back in until about 30 days after

Message.Title: DeMark's Update: prepare for launch
Message.Msg: DeMark's 13 exhaustion selling was a clear indication the selling was done in AAPL, but that was before AAPL reported low guidance and spooked everyone comined with doing nothing to defend the shares, at least yet, with the massive excess liquidity. Now the shares are trudging of very low volume -- exhausted selling -- toward another key day count. No low guidance coming next week -- more like news on the $4.5B Turkish iPad deal. We're all for something on using capital to support the stock, too... and maybe the Company os ready to show us why Gore has only praise for Cook's leadership (China Mobile timing/product answers any day now). Unhedged shorts desrve a good fry pan trip.

Topic.Title: option ideas

Message.Msg: not a chance, I hate to say it but I think we might have seen AAPL top out, they need some major catalysts to make another run in the stock, I am thinking any of these will work: stock split, larger dividend, put some of the cash to work, new products, take market share in more markets, etc. at the moment, AAPL is turning into a pretty good trading stock, nothing more, I do not see a short squeeze imminent, and this stock has become notorious for being manipulated because of weekly options. Best days to buy AAPL is late Friday and Mondays, volatility is then sucked out by week's end when options expire.

Topic.Title: didn't the last time Demark get it wrong?...

Message.Msg: wait didn't he call a run up to $515 heading into earnings? He came on to promote the fact that he got long the stock and once it reached his target, probably got into puts before earnings cuz the word was out, look at the stock price action, AAPL usually has a much larger run into earnings, not this time, at this point the stock is in no man's land, and it really is hard to make a case for an imminent rebound without some catalyst? If they really believe the growth story is still in place, why are they not in there buying up their stock via buyback, or increase dividend, or here is one, split the stock, if they do, that will be huge. But they do not, has never been an investor friendly company really, always built themselves up to be growth via innovation and stock price appreciation, which in reality it has been, but I am afraid the fact that they have not cut into competitor's market share tells me they are in need of some needed innovation on how to grow from here.
